prop.head.headtext: Confidential Business Information in Historical Context
Policy Reasons for Protection of Confidential Information

head.headtext: Provision of Economic Incentives for Individual Inventors

para.paratext: Given the protection of confidential business information, the investor will know that, if reasonable means are used to keep the information secret, the investor will be able to recoup his or her investment with relatively little risk from poachers. In a market economy, the courts uphold the right of an innovator to the market value of an idea as long as he or she is the bona fide owner of the idea.[1] It is argued that without the protection of confidential business information, groups such as manufacturers and publishers would not fund research.[2]
G.F. Takach, Patents: A Canadian Compendium of Law and Practice (Edmonton: Juriliber, 1993).

R.G. Hammond, “The Misappropriation of Commercial Information in the Computer Age” (1986), 64 Can. Bar Rev. 342 at pp. 344-7; T. Robison, “The Confidence Game: An Approach to the Law about Trade Secrets” (1983), 25 Ariz. L.R. 346.
